awd_titl_txt: HBCU-Excellence in Research: Understanding Atmospheric Moist Convection and Organization Using Automatic Feature Identification and Tracking
awd_abstract_narration:
Convective updraft core and its lifecycle are fundamental processes in atmospheric moist convection. Cumulus parameterization is a critical component in global climate prediction. The ultimate goal of the study is to improve cumulus parameterization using a physically based, time-variant convective updraft core concept. The close collaborations between the PI and Co-PI will add new research field (atmospheric sciences) and strengthen the current research and teaching (computer sciences) at Morgan State University, an HBCU (Historically Black Colleges and Universities) that has been recently designated as Maryland's preeminent public urban research university. An education component is built into the study, where a graduate student and an undergraduate student will be supported and trained in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) field at Morgan State University.

Coherent updraft cores are the engine for convective heat and moisture transport. However, systematic study of convective updraft cores from a Lagrangian point of view has not been performed before. This project will take advantages of existing computer image recognition and machine learning algorithms, adapt them to high resolution cloud-resolving model simulations, in order to automatically identify updraft core features and track them throughout their full life cycle. Three sets of progressively more sophisticated simulations will be carried out: ensemble simulations of triggered single convection, quasi-equilibrium state simulation, and case studies using observed large-scale forcing. Convective updraft core characteristics such as their sizes, depths, lifespan and spatial distributions will be derived from these simulations. Model sensitivity tests that perturb environmental conditions, e.g., stability, water vapor, wind shear, will reveal environmental controls on updraft core characteristics. 

Convection organization will also be studied in the context of updraft cores through their congregation, merging and splitting.  Although not immediately achievable in the framework of current project, the ultimate goal is to use the time-variant convective core concept established in this study to improve cumulus parameterization in global climate predictions. A database including thousands of convective updraft cores and their lifecycles will be compiled and made public through this project for further study.

This is an interdisciplinary study that takes advantage of existing data mining and machine learning algorithms in information sciences and applies them to 3D wind fields where convection is embedded. Identifying and tracking updraft cores is a novel approach that will provide new insights to dynamics and physics of moist convection and its organization. The time-dependent updraft core concept can potentially be used to replace the steady state plume model in current GCM cumulus parameterizations, allowing for a scale-independent cumulus parameterization with a physical underlying concept.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Atmospheric convection is a fundamental component of vigorous precipitation systems such ashurricanes and squall lines. It serves as the engineof global atmospheric circulations through the latent heat released during the convection process. Understanding the fundamentals of atmospheric convection not only enhances our comprehension of atmospheric dynamics and improves weather forecasts but also aids in improving future climate predictions. This is achieved by refining the parameterization of convection in Global Climate Models (GCMs), where convection cannot be explicitly resolved. Our project aims to analyze the characteristics and evolution of convective cores, the intense updraft regions in storms that define precipitation systems, using a database simulated by a high-resolution cloud-resolving model.

In this research, we employed both unsupervised and supervised machine learning algorithms to enable efficient and accurate identification and segmentation of convective cores. We adapted existing 3D computer image segmentation algorithms to analyze three-dimensional data from cloud-resolving simulations. The workflow we have established is as following: First, clustering techniques and the Pyclesperanto 3D segmentation algorithm were tailored for 3D convective core segmentation and applied to the simulated vertical velocity field Second, human validation was conducted, and inaccuracies were manually corrected, particularly for cells undergoing merging and splitting. Finally, the validated dataset was used to train deep learning algorithms such as 3D UNet, enabling rapid and precise identification and labeling of convective cells using advanced machine learning techniques.

We selected the 3D Residual UNet with post-processing as the primary production algorithm due to its better performance. Using the trained UNet model, we analyzed three cloud-resolving model simulations with varying aerosol number concentrations to investigate the impact of aerosols on convection. Our findings indicate that aerosols primarily invigorate convection by intensifying individual convective cells, particularly the stronger ones. However, the number of convective cells and their average sizes remain relatively unchanged.

Broader Impacts:

This EiR grant provided invaluable research opportunities for students at a historically Black university. By leveraging this grant alongside other funding sources, we supported six undergraduate and four graduate students. The grant fostered collaborations between computer science and atmospheric science disciplines, introducing atmospheric science concepts to computer science majors. Notably, one electrical engineering student secured a position in an atmospheric science-related field as a direct result of the grant support.

Additionally, the cloud-resolving model simulations generated a unique dataset that benefit computer science research and training. It addresses the demand for 3D labeled data in machine learning research and applications. The convective core data were also used in virtual reality exercises for computer vision student training. This interdisciplinary approach underscores the dual benefits of advancing atmospheric science while contributing to cutting-edge machine learning applications.
